history.comment:
Edited. Please retract duplicate https://pleiades.stoa.org/places/678393/sidunu-2. Moreover, note that Sidūnu (with a normal s) is not a valid form for the time period Neo-Assyrian/Babylonian Middle East (720–540 BC).

names.description: Ṣidūnu ṣehru ("lesser Sidon") is mentioned with Ṣidūnu rabû ("greater Sidon") in inscriptions of the Assyrian king Sennacherib (r. 704-681 BC). The name probably refers to an area of Sidon, perhaps the island portion of the city or its suburbs.

history.comment: Edited
Edited
Initial revision

references.formattedCitation: Bagg, Ariel M, Wolfgang Röllig, Dietz Otto Edzard, Brigitte Groneberg, Ḫālid Nāšif, Giuseppe F Del Monte, Ran Zadok, et al. Répertoire géographique des textes cunéiformes 7,1 7,1. Tübinger Atlas des Vorderen Orients / Beihefte / B, 7,7,1. Wiesbaden: Reichert, 2007. http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/230137758.

names.description: Ṣidūnu rabû ("greater Sidon") is mentioned with Ṣidūnu ṣehru ("lesser Sidon") in inscriptions of the Assyrian king Sennacherib (r. 704-681 BC). The name probably refers to an area of Sidon, perhaps the mainland portion or the central part of the city.

history.comment: Initial revision

names.description: Name of Sidon in Assyrian royal inscriptions dating to the reigns of Sennacherib (r. 704-681 BC) and Esarhaddon (r. 680-669 BC).

names.description: Ethnic name used to designate a person from Sidon in Neo-Assyrian sources, especially in royal inscriptions.
